head.headtext: Privilege against self-incrimination—Privilege of a witness not to testify to incriminating facts

para.paratext: The privilege against self-incrimination is not limited to criminal defendants. Any witness has a privilege not to testify to incriminating facts. In addition to the protections offered in the constitutions of the United States and Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 24-5-505 provides:

(a) No party or witness shall be required to testify as to any matter which may incriminate or tend to incriminate such party or witness or which shall tend to bring infamy, disgrace, or public contempt upon such party or witness or any member of such party or witness's family.

(b) Except in proceedings in which a judgment creditor or judgment creditor's successor in interest seeks post judgment discovery involving a judgment debtor pursuant to Code Section 9-11-69, no party or witness shall be required to testify as to any matter which shall tend to work a forfeiture of his estate.
(c) No official persons shall be called on to disclose any state matters of which the policy of the state and the interest of the community require concealment.

When a criminal defendant takes the stand as a witness, he waives his privilege against self-incrimination. All other witnesses, however, retain the privilege when appearing before any judicial, legislative, or administrative official or body (civil or criminal) that has the power to compel attendance and testimony. A party testifying in a civil action may claim the privilege.[
1] If a non-party witness elects to waive his privilege and testify, the parties cannot object since the privilege belongs to the witness and not the parties.[
2]

Generally, a witness may claim the privilege against self-incrimination while testifying if an answer would expose the witness to a penalty or forfeiture by operation of law because this is a “criminal case” within the meaning of the Fifth Amendment to the federal Constitution.[
3] In the earliest Georgia case on point, Marshall v. Riley, [4] the Georgia Supreme Court held that, in discovery under an 1847 statute, a party need not reveal any fact that would tend to subject him to a penalty or punishment.

However, a witness may not claim the privilege just because an answer might subject him to civil liability or because he might lose his job.[
5] Also, unlike a criminal defendant, an ordinary witness cannot make a blanket assertion of his privilege against self-incrimination. However, it is within the trial court's discretion to refuse to make a co-indictee take the witness stand.[
6]

Witnesses may only assert privilege in response to specific questions.[
7] When a witness invokes the privilege against self-incrimination, the trial court must first determine if the danger of self-incrimination is real and appreciable. If so, the decision whether to invoke the privilege must be left to the witness. Only if the trial court determines that the answer could not incriminate the witness must the witness testify.[
8]

The privilege recognized in O.C.G.A. § 24-5-505 allows a witness to assert the privilege where an answer would bring not only criminal sanction but also “infamy or disgrace or public contempt” upon the witness or any member of his family. This extension of the privilege has received little judicial consideration, and, even in those cases, the provision has minimal effect.

In Brooks v. State ,[9] the Georgia Supreme Court construed the language of former O.C.G.A. § 24-9-27 to require a witness to answer questions tending to bring infamy, disgrace, or public contempt upon himself or his family if the proposed evidence is material to the issues in the case. Apparently, “it is only where the proposed answer has no effect on the case except to impair the witness' credibility that the witness may fall back on the privilege.”
[10]

The court in Brown v. State [11] followed the reasoning in Brooks in holding an attorney was required to answer questions which may establish that he ineffectively assisted his client, even though the answers may tend to bring him into public disgrace or contempt, because “the materiality of the evidence outweigh[ed] the testimonial privilege.”
[12]

However, the Georgia Supreme Court allowed witnesses to assert the privilege under former O.C.G.A. § 24-9-27 (now O.C.G.A. § 24-5-505) in civil actions involving proof of sexual relationships if the testimony would tend to bring “infamy or disgrace or public contempt” on the witness regardless of the materiality of the testimony.[
13]

The witness may only invoke the privilege in response to specific questions.[
14] Several cases[15] have stated that the witness, not the judge, determines whether the answer would incriminate him. Procedurally, the judge first determines if an answer might incriminate the witness and then the witness decides whether to claim the privilege.[
16] This means that the witness knows what his answer would be and can claim the privilege if a truthful answer would incriminate him. It does not mean that the witness can decide on the nature of the question. Chief Justice Marshall in U.S. v. Burr[17] made a classic statement regarding this situation:

It is the province of the court to judge whether any direct answer to the question which may be proposed will furnish evidence against the witness. If such answer may disclose a fact which forms a necessary and essential link in the chain of testimony which would be sufficient to convict him of any crime, he is not bound to answer it so as to furnish matter for that conviction. In such a case, the witness must himself judge what his answer will be, and if he says, on oath, that he cannot answer without accusing himself, he cannot be compelled to answer.

This assumes that the court finds a substantial probability of danger of self-incrimination to the witness from the question. Similarly, the Georgia Court of Appeals has stated that “[t]he appropriate course of action when a witness invokes the privilege against self-incrimination is for the trial court first to determine if the danger of self-incrimination is ‘real and appreciable.’”
[18] “If so, the decision whether to invoke the privilege must be left to the witness. Only if the trial court determines the answer could not incriminate the witness, must the witness testify.”
[19]

The privilege must be expressly invoked by the witness. A witness cannot invoke the privilege through silence.[
20]

In Townsend v. Northcutt ,[21] the defendant responded to interrogatories by stating under oath: “I refuse to answer on the grounds that this may tend to incriminate me and work a forfeiture of my estate.”
The Georgia Court of Appeals held that this properly raised the claim of privilege. In Temple v. Temple ,[22] the defendant refused to answer 29 questions at a deposition “on advice of counsel.” The Georgia Supreme Court held that it was plain that the witness had invoked his privilege against self-incrimination.

If a witness claims his privilege and refuses to testify to certain facts, the question arises as to whether the fact-finder may draw a negative inference from the claim of privilege. It is a logical inference that, if a witness claims his privilege against self-incrimination, then a truthful answer would in fact incriminate him. In the case of a nonparty witness, no inference can be drawn against a party.[
23]

The question is slightly different where a party testifies as a witness and claims his privilege against self-incrimination. The court considered this question of first impression in Simpson v. Simpson ,[24] which involved the custody of minor children. In that case, the mother (party) and a friend (witness) claimed their privilege against self-incrimination and refused to answer questions concerning their alleged illicit conduct. The question presented was whether a negative inference could be drawn against the party—mother—to sustain the award of custody to the father. The court held that no inference of guilt could be drawn from the claim of privilege against self-incrimination in a criminal case nor could the claim in a civil case be used in a subsequent criminal case against the witness, but a negative inference might be drawn when a party testifies as a witness in a civil case and claims the privilege against self-incrimination.[
25]

The state may not impose substantial penalties upon a non-immunized witness who elects to exercise his Fifth Amendment right not to give incriminating testimony.[
26] On the other hand, if a witness's claim of privilege is improperly denied and the witness is forced to testify, a criminal defendant has no standing to claim error.[
27]

In some instances, the privilege against self-incrimination protects a witness from being made to appear at a criminal trial. In Dodd v. State ,[28] the defendant subpoenaed a co-indictee whose attorney informed the trial judge that the witness would claim his privilege against self-incrimination. The trial judge properly quashed the subpoena because it was not necessary to put the witness on the stand to claim his privilege.

As a general rule in criminal cases, a party is not entitled to call a witness for the sole purpose of having the witness exercise his privilege against self-incrimination before the jury.[
29] A witness should be allowed to assert his privilege against self-incrimination outside the presence of the jury and no comment may be made about the witness's assertion during the trial of the case. Neither side of a criminal case “has the right to benefit from any inferences the jury may draw simply from the witness' assertion of the privilege either alone or in conjunction with questions that have been put to him.”
[30] This is not the case in civil practice as the trier of fact may draw negative inferences against a party who chooses to assert his privilege against self-incrimination.[
31]
A witness may lose any right to invoke the privilege against self-incrimination if the trial court grants an order of immunity pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 24-5-507(a):[32]

Whenever in the judgment of the Attorney General or any district attorney the testimony of any person or the production of evidence of any kind by any person in any criminal proceeding before a court or grand jury is necessary to the public interest, the Attorney General or the district attorney may request in writing the superior court to order such person to testify or produce the evidence. Upon order of the court, such person shall not be excused on the basis of his privilege against self-incrimination from testifying or producing any evidence required, but no testimony or other evidence required under the order or any information directly or indirectly derived from such testimony or evidence shall be used against the person in any proceedings or prosecution for a crime or offense concerning which he or she testified or produced evidence under court order. However, such person may nevertheless be prosecuted or subjected to penalty or forfeiture for any perjury, false swearing, or contempt committed in testifying or failing to testify or in producing or failing to produce evidence in accordance with the order but shall not be required to produce evidence that can be used in any other courts in this state, the United States, or any other state. Any order entered under this Code section shall be entered of record in the minutes of the court so as to afford a permanent record thereof, and any testimony given by a person pursuant to such order shall be transcribed and filed for permanent record in the office of the clerk of the court.

This Code section provides for the grant of unconditional “use and derivative use” immunity to a witness.[
33] The attorney general or the district attorney can make a request that the court order the witness to testify.[
34]

However, nothing in the statute mandates that the court enter an order compelling a witness's testimony automatically upon the state's request. If the witness is granted immunity under O.C.G.A. § 24-5-507(a) and still refuses to testify after being so compelled by the court, the statute provides that the witness may be “adjudged in contempt and committed to the county jail until such time as such person purges himself or herself of contempt by testifying as ordered.”
[35] Thus, the grant of an order of immunity under this Code section removes any right to invoke the privilege. As recognized by the Georgia Court of Appeals, “to hold otherwise would render the immunity statute meaningless because any witness would be able to continue to assert the privilege against self-incrimination regardless of a grant of immunity.”
[36]

Even if the state has granted immunity to the witness, counsel may not ask leading questions once a witness asserts privilege and refuses to answer. In Horne v. State ,[37] the trial court permitted a prosecutor to ask an immunized witness a series of leading questions despite the witness' assertion of his privilege against self-incrimination and refusal to testify. The Georgia Supreme Court held that this practice violated the criminal defendant's right to confront witnesses against him under the Sixth Amendment of the United States Constitution. While the questions posed to the witness and the witness's refusal to answer were not evidence, the undeniable effect of this prosecutorial procedure was to place before jury, through the questions asked, the content of witness's statement to police and the clear inference of defendant's guilt. The trial court did not contemporaneously give the jury any limiting instructions and the witness could not be cross-examined on a statement imputed to, but not admitted by, him. It is not, however, error for the court to inform a witness that, while testifying under a grant of immunity, the immunity does not mean “that you can come in here and lie and say anything you want.”
[38]

In Hanson v. State ,[39 ] the Georgia Court of Appeals considered a grant of transactional immunity by the district attorney that had been approved by the trial judge. While “use and derivative use immunity” protects witness from the use of either incriminating testimony or fruits of such testimony against them, “transactional immunity” is much broader and protects the person testifying from prosecution for any transaction touched on in his testimony whether or not his involvement can be independently proven. Although former O.C.G.A. § 24-9-28 (now O.C.G.A. § 24-5-507) provides only for the grant of “use and derivative use” immunity, the Hanson Court held that, even in the absence of statutory authority, trial courts had power to grant transactional immunity.

In holding that no common law transactional immunity existed in Georgia and that the defendant in Hanson was not entitled to the statutory “use and derivative use” immunity, the Georgia Supreme Court reviewed the entire area of immunity and set out some guidelines with respect to the grant of such immunity.[
40] The Court found that the prosecutor has discretion to dismiss cases prior to indictment but, by analogy to a nolle prosequi, he must obtain court approval in the future where there is a promise to forego prosecution. In such cases, the promise must be limited to specific crimes or transactions. The promise in Hanson was too broad, but would be enforced as to the indictment in that case.

Generally, when considering whether to enforce agreements between defendants and prosecuting attorneys, Georgia courts have analyzed them under the principles of contract law.[
41] Thus, while the state's agreement in Hanson to forgo prosecution of any unnamed offenses occurring within the county during a certain time period was unenforceable, the Supreme Court found the promise binding as to the dismissal of specific charges.[
42]

In Simpson, a father's case for a change in custody was based largely on proof of conduct of the mother and a third-party witness. Based on claims of the privilege against self-incrimination, the mother and the witness declined to answer questions about their conduct. As a matter of first impression, the Georgia Supreme Court considered whether or not an inference could be drawn against the mother from the claim of privilege. The Court reviewed the rule that no inference could be drawn in a criminal case against a defendant based on his claim of the privilege in that case or in any other proceedings. Acknowledging that the rule did not control in a civil case, the Court held that an inference against the mother could be drawn by the fact finder, here the trial judge, because of the claim of privilege.
